segments.text: Your name is?
Please tell me your name.
My name?
Romulo, Romulo Munguia Torres.
And where were you born?
In Guadalajara.
In Guadalajara?
In what year?
Well, during these days in the past, tell me about your life when you were young in Guadalajara.
It took me about ten years.
My mother had nine children.
I was the second of the men, but I was the fifth in the family.
Los anteriores murieron y fueron dos, y hubo dos mujeres.
De manera que yo fui el quinto de la familia.
Entonces, empezamos a luchar de una manera muy violenta, dado que mi padre,
He was persecuted by the government of General Díaz.
He died because of the persecution of General Díaz.
My father was a supporter of General Ramón Corona.
He was the governor of the state.
He pacified the whole region.
In what year did his father die?
How old was I?
I was 95.
I was about 10 years old.
My mother stayed in front of the family, and two older sisters were the ones who were working, being old ladies, to support us.
I sweep the streets because at that time the owners of the houses had to sweep the streets every day.
I sweep the streets in some houses to earn a few cents and help my sisters or help with some cents that they gave me also because I helped mass in a church.
Con eso nos fuimos formando.
Hasta que una de mis hermanas se casó.
Se fue a México.
Y entonces me llevó junto con otra hermana, la más chica.
Y allí en México fue donde empecé prácticamente a maquiar.
Allí entré de aprendiz.
en una imprenta que se llamó American Book and Printing Company, que hacía todo el trabajo de los ferrocarriles en aquella época.
De ahí fui progresando hasta que llegué a ser jefe del departamento recreativo.
Entonces,
There I met Mr. Ernesto Chiavero, who founded the first magazine for the place, an illustrated magazine called Arte y Letras.
I sympathized with him, and then he put on his apron and took me there as her boss.
There I was working
until the newspaper, El Diario, was founded to compete with El Impartial, which was the main newspaper in Mexico.
And then, in El Diario, I became the head of the workshops.
From there, practically,
The social struggle began to explode.
I established the National Labor Chamber in Mexico in 1910.
With that, the social struggle began.
that was associated with the revolution.
And to the triumph of Madero, they recognized us and we started to work.
The Department of Labor was established by Don Francisco León de la Barra and we solved the first strike that took place.
So they started working in accordance with the capital and the work.
But after two or three years, Morones and other individuals came to defend themselves.
We could now call them communists.
And the fight between them and us began.
Then, after Madero fell, we withdrew from the fight and the Moronistas stayed, right?
They started to establish trade unions and to exploit the workers, inciting them to strike and fight.
So then, the social struggle in Mexico was bifurcated.
I, with the part... the part... How could we call it?
Moderate, if you want.
And Morones with the radical part.
So, the fall of Madero came, and even Obregón came.
And Jorones accompanied him with Obregón and the social struggle began.
We could say that.
And I, well, I incorporated myself from the opposite side to the death of Madero, who was already Don Venustiano Carranza,
So I became a member of Don Venustiano.
And since then I started my revolutionary struggle in Mexico.
Then came the separation between Villa and Don Venustiano.
Don Venustiano left Mexico and went to Veracruz.
And I was in Puebla, always with Macabrasismo, and I established a newspaper called Nueva Patria.
That newspaper was to take the workers down a path of reconciliation between capital and work.
Tomando como tema principal para poderles meter en la cabeza a los trabajadores cuál era nuestro papel, adopté como ejemplo el desarrollo de una empresa de ferrocarril.
Les empecé a demostrar que el capital y el trabajo debían de caminar como se construyen los rieles de una.
for a railway.
That if one deviates from the other due to little deviation, the society in general, which in this case simulated the machine for the cars, would deviate.
And that was the danger of the clothes fight.
se descargaría la sociedad y entonces tendríamos que ir al fracaso.
Pero como luego vino el asesinato de... Entonces, cuando me metieron en México, me mandaron a Yucatán.
and in Yucatán we established a newspaper, the newspaper was called Demócrata.
From Mérida I went to San Juan Bautista, in Tabasco, and I also established the Demócrata.
And once the social campaign was established in these two regions,
I was ordered to go to Tapachula, in Chiapas, on the border of Guatemala.
But in San Juan Bautista, I got a very strong paludism, and then I was ordered to go back to Mexico.
I re-concentrated in Mexico with the column of General Don Pablo González.
And Don Pablo...
The general of Cabanza?
Yes.
So Don Pablo sent me to Puebla to establish also the labor campaign in favor of
of the moderate movement.
And I established there the immense unions of workers.
I established the newspaper, which was also called El Demócrata.
And already in Puebla came the electoral struggle
Y se nombró el Congreso Constituyente, Congreso de Querétaro.
Y en el congreso, en este congreso, fui yo representante por el distrito de Camachaco, del Estado de Ecuador.
Ya, ya, entonces,
Se siguió la lucha entre Obregón y Carranza hasta llegar al asesinato de Don Balistiano.
Asesinado Don Balistiano, Don Pablo, que era mi jefe de hija, tuvo que venir a los Estados Unidos.
And they started chasing us, the demonists.
And that's when I had to leave Mexico to come here to the United States.
Since then, I've been here.
I couldn't return to Mexico until General Cardenas
But I didn't want to go because I already have my family, I already have my children here.
For a few years, it was no longer worth it to move them to go to the revolution.
Here I came and I started working with Ignacio Lozano in the press.
And after three months of being here, he made me head of the press, the superintendent of the press.
After a few years, after three or four or five years, I had a discussion with the father of Enrique González, who was the president of the press.
And Don Ignacio was in Los Angeles.
And there I told Don Ignacio to take me away from the press.
And I took him away.
I stayed on the street with three or four children to fight.
And I started working with a small press.
From there, step by step, we have come to this.
That has been, in general terms, what I have been able to do.
To educate my children, that they are grateful to this country, that it received them from childhood.
They have occupied and played a very important role.
And during the war, they have united as warriors.
Without losing their love for Mexico, but always their loyalty to the country that educated them.
That's how we are.
Formado esta pequeña familia.
¿Y toda su familia vivía ahora en San Antonio?
Pues, el mayor está en Detroit.
Allá tiene un taller de imprenta.
Es presidente de la sociedad de oficiales.
the retired chiefs and officers, because he spent 23 years in the army, and he left as lieutenant colonel.
He retired and has a full job, and he continues to work as... he is in his services, in what is necessary in the army, of course.
El otro segundo es este, Rubén.
Este nada más sirvió su periodo y se vino conmigo.
Y ha sido el que conmigo ha levantado el negocio.
El turcero Guillermo está en Randolph Hill.
No, Lackland Hill.
They are also retired.
She just retired.
She was an assistant to the general and chief of all the air forces in the Pacific.
Well, then...
So, where are we now?
Yes.
Well, we established a society for teaching Spanish, right?
Yes.
And we created a... My daughter, my granddaughter.
Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you too.
My daughter is from a university.
Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you.
Thank you.
Yes, yes.
Tiene su historia.
Como le dije a usted, cuando nos tuvimos que venir a los Estados Unidos, entré a trabajar a la prensa.
Y allí me hice ese mal bendijo.
A los tres meses, me nombró jefe de los talleres Don Nacho Lozano.
Durante todo ese tiempo, pues,
Estuve trabajando bien, pero llegó el momento en el que Don Ignacio fundó en Los Ángeles el periódico La Opinión.
Y entonces, él se fue a vigilar allá.
El papá de Enrique González, Don Leonides, quedó al frente del negocio de la prensa.
But because of Angas or Marangas, as we say in Spanish, there was a disagreement between him and me, and I had to separate.
So a real calvary began for me.
Because my wife had to do the laundry.
And the boys, Rafael and Rubén, who were already grown up, started selling a magazine called Liberty.
And for every copy they sold, they gave them a coupon.
Con el tiempo, llegaron a juntar una cantidad de copones y entré en el catálogo que les daban de premios a cambio de copones.
Estaba una precita que cuando la vimos en el catálogo, me preguntaron los muchachos, papá, ¿quieres que pedamos esta precita?
Sí, hijo, pídanla.
Y pidieron la prensa y la tenían como juguete.
Yo estaba trabajando.
Pero vino el disgusto y me tuve que separar.
Y entonces mi señora fundó un programa de radio que se llamó La Hora Estrella.
Pero los comerciantes,
In spite of the program, they began to ask that there be a male announcer, that it wasn't all announced by my wife.
And then I asked for permission from Don Leonides to allow me to go out at 3 in the afternoon
to help my wife.
The program was from three to four.
But we were in that when the displeasure came.
And then we stayed.
My wife had to be washed.
And at that time there were factories where they cleaned nuts.
And we also started to march, in short, as humbly as we could.
And one night, when we didn't have anything to feed the creatures, like at 11 o'clock at night, my wife and I were sad to see that the boys had been taken to bed
sin cenar, sin comer.
Y me quedé viendo la fresita.
Entonces le dije a mi señora, oye, después de todo, ¿por qué nos quedamos?
Desde mañana tengo mi imprenta.
Entonces me dice, ¿pero qué estás loco?
¿Con qué?
Le digo, mira,
That's going to be our salvation.
That's going to be our imprint.
No, you're crazy.
We're going to sleep.
The next day, very early, I went to see this man.
What was his name?
He was the agent of the Dillinger mills in New Brompton.
here in San Antonio.
And I told him, man, he was the announcer of the radio program of my lady.
I told him, man, why don't we make a combination?
To announce the flour, let's make some coupons.
And those coupons, you give them to the merchants so that they give them to the consumers of the flour.
He said, man, it's good.
So we started to make up to 10,000 popcorns.
We did it on the square.
The boys, instead of leaving school, and instead of going out with their friends, they came to help me with the machine.
Well, that's how God did it.
From this machine, we bought another one.
a bigger one, and a bigger one, and a second-hand one, all broken, in short.
We kept raising them until they reached you.
So this is the basis of Mugia Principa.
And this has drawn a lot of attention, this principle, right?
They have been published on several occasions.
In typography exhibitions in the schools, they come in the front.
Ah, este es un artículo sobre usted.
Sí.
Sí?
Ah, qué interesante.
Is it possible for me to read this on the tape, please?
Yes.
To make a copy.
Toy Presley to Prosperity by J.H.
Pling, staff writer.
Sit down.
San Antonio Express, Sunday, September 30, 1951.
One of the West Side's leading citizens is not a citizen.

That seeming paradox simply means Rumalo Munguia, Sr., who parlayed a Tory press into a big print shop in Prospect Hill, has been accepting duties and obligations of citizenship minus the privileges such as voting.
and so forth.
You can read English in fields.
He moved to San Antonio in 1926 as a political exile after taking the losing de la Huerta side in the struggle for power with the Obregon Calles Morones group.
He and his family lived through the rough days of the Depression and stripped the bottom of their barrel of resources.
But as he fought through it to his business success, Munguia said he became convinced that the United States is still a land of plenty of opportunity.
Born in .
Born in Guadalajara, Munguia got printer's ink in his blood as a young boy while working as an apprentice in El Sol Print Shop.
He was in the thick of the revolution that broke out in 1910 against the political and economic oppression of Porfirio Díaz until 1920 when the de la Huerta group split with Obregón.
Munguil was in the army as a public information officer setting up newspapers throughout the Puebla zone.
He was named a delegate to the 1917 Constitutional Convention but did not attend because he was on active duty.
Bueno, eso es muy interesante.
Sí, muy interesante.
Díganme un poco más sobre estos días cuando usted salió de México.
Cuando usted viene a Texas, sí.
¿Cómo?
¿Cómo de qué?
Pues más como sus experiencias durante estos días.
¿Es una cosa de peligroso o...?
En 1926, cuando usted viene por Texas.
¿Cuando yo vine?
Sí.
It was precisely because Obregón was chasing me.
And precisely the night that I crossed the border here, that night they looked for me in the house in Puebla to help me.
They only found my wife and some children.
So if I hadn't left Puebla the day I left, the next day they would have shot me in front of the house, in the Cerro de Guadalupe, in Puebla.
So I arrived here precisely on the day of my saint, on the 11th of January,
I came here in 1926, so if they had arrested me there, on the day of my death, I would have been executed.
So that's when I started working here at the press.
And your wife, how did she come to you?
In October, I got the passports because I was already settled here, I already had my job.
So I gave permission to the government to let me come.
Yes.
And there are no problems with the passport?
No.
So we didn't have any problems.
And since then my wife came with Rafael, Rubén, Guillermo and Ylvira.
They were the four children who came from there.
The others were born here.
Where are you from?
Where in Mexico are you from?
From Puebla.
From Puebla?
From Puebla.
Did you meet her after you went to Puebla?
Yes, when I arrived in Puebla with the revolution, that's where I met her.
Yes.
That's where I met her.
Because she...
When we went to Puebla, the country was more or less still.
It was when the Constituent Congress was held in 1917.
I was also the first councilor of the town hall and I was the director of the public welfare.
until the mission of Obregón arrived and I had to come.
Since then I have been fighting here.
The first job, after I left the press, was when I started my social work, we could go here.
And then we established the first school
in the summer, in Spanish, for children to speak Spanish.
Yes.
At the Navarro School.
Yes.
Here in...
It was here on Fecos Street.
There, during the holidays, we had Spanish schools.
That's nice.
Yes.
That's how we started.
Then, after I started working,
por establecer la biblioteca mexicana.
Y logramos que se estableciera la biblioteca.
Mandó a México algunos ejemplares y aquí se fue haciendo.
Pero la cuestión política y las intrigas en las organizaciones siempre, ¿verdad?
Se murió, podríamos decir, se clausuró la biblioteca.
Y entonces pensamos en otra forma y establecimos los cursos de extensión universitaria de acuerdo con la Universidad de México.
Todo eso pues lo tengo en archivo, ¿verdad?
Y fue por el año de 19...
In 1940, we started little by little in a school, then in another school, the superior, then Bracken Ridge.
From Bracken Ridge we went to Trinity, to Trinity and here, until we managed to definitively stay in Trinity.
Here it is, here it is.
Ah, dos palabras.
Uno de los programas culturales desarrollados durante el año 1963 fue el presentado del 7 de julio por el doctor José San Martín de la estación radio de Cusura que debía EXTV.
Sí.
Sí.
Yes, very interesting.
About 50 years of Mexican culture in San Antonio, Texas.
Excuse me, there's someone waiting for you.
Do you want me to tell them where you're here?
Yes, you can show them in.
I guess it's my daughter.
Mi hija está aquí.
Oh, do you want me to bring her up here?
Well, bring them both up here.
That'd be fun.
¿Es bueno?
¿Quieres encontrar con mi hija?
Yo quiero... ¿Esto puede usted conservarla?
¿Es de Trinity University?
Sí.
Precisamente cómo se fundaron los cursos.
Sí, sobre los cursos.
Ah, sí.
Y este es el trabajo de usted.
Sí.
Sí, qué bonito.
Tell me a little more about your experience with Mr. Lázaro Cárdenas, the one you invited to come back to Mexico.
Yes, Lázaro Cárdenas was a boy who was also an apprentice of printing, like me.
Yes, yes.
But then he came
The revolution came and we all separated.
And we didn't see each other again.
But we brought the two of us.
We were already created in the same school.
We already felt the desire for improvement.
He understood through the profession of the peasants and I through the industrial part.
So we were separated, he by his side and I by mine, without any contact.
But when he came to the presidency, the director of the national newspaper, Froylan Manjarrez, came in.
And Froylan Manjarrez was a...
a journalist who became the governor of Puebla, whom I initiated.
I helped him to become a constituent deputy, also, for Atlixco.
So when he came in, he got together with Cárdenas,
So he remembered me.
And then he called me.
And then I told Prolán that he couldn't come.
That he was already settled.
And that I was taking care of my children.
And that was the reason.
That's how things are.
I didn't come back with a political passion, but when Cárdenas came in for the first time, I received him.
I have all the photographs that we took with him.
I was with San Antonio all the time.
Then he went to Russia and he got along with the communists.
I didn't have any interest anymore.
I told them, I'm more or less settled, my children are getting educated in a way that I don't want to go back.
And then I dedicated myself to organizing here the festivals of May 5, September 16, all organized by me.
From all that I have photographs and data and everything.
But it would be a very long question for you to see the process, right?
Yes.
But here you can see something of how it was done until it was finally achieved, that the university was established.
I don't know if there is any here.
Como les digo a ustedes, pues, tengo una casa.
Estas son las carátulas de los programas que... Programa de fiestas patrias mexicanas.
Sí.
Sí, y también... Mi ciudad madre, Guadalajara.
Su familia, toda su familia estaba de Guadalajara originalmente.
Sí.
Qué interesante.
And my daughter, Mary Catherine.
Ah, this one is also very interesting.
I want to read it, yes.
You can keep this one as an example.
What?
You can keep it as an example.
For you.
Oh, it's for me?
Yes.
Oh, well, thank you.
But this one, no.
This one, no.
No, yes.
Well, thank you.
In this case, it is not necessary to read it.
Well, do you know Obregón?
I don't know Obregón.
No?
Never?
No, never, because we were always on the opposite side.
Obregón was in the north, and I was in Yucatán with the Barats.
We were separated, but personally I don't know him.
And you met Mr. Cárdenas.
What kind of man was Mr. Cárdenas?
Very well-intentioned.
The same as Zapata.
Zapata was such a good man.
Very good that he was Zapata.
He was naturally down there.
No, no se puede controlar porque la revolución no se hace con gente decente.
Se hace con el pueblo.
Y tenemos que echar mano de lo malo para poder tener gente.
Porque con gente decente no se hace la revolución.
But you knew Mr. Zapata?
Yes, I knew him.
I knew Zapata, I knew his brother.
I was in contact with many Zapatista bosses.
Then some Zapatista bosses were with me.
I was in contact with General Domingo Arenas, who was one of the most addicted to Zapata.
Yes, yes.
Zapata was a very good person.
Well, during these years, from 1920 to 1926, what kind of work did you have in Mexico?
Since... After the revolution...
I had my newspaper.
Ah, yes.
It's called...
It's called The Liberal.
Ah, yes.
In Puebla?
In Puebla.
Yes.
He had a little organ.
